answers.author: Derek Johnson
answers.text:
Toni,
ICMA has an entire topic page devoted to 311:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/1/311CRM_Systems
The page will connect you with 311 experts, allow you to pose questions and access a range of introductory documents on 311 call systems and related best practices. That's as good a place as any to start. 
Good luck,
Derek Johnson

answers.author: Cory Fleming
answers.text:
Toni - You will likely get lots of calls about services that are outside your jurisdiction, but it's up to city leaders to determine how far they want to go in responding to those types of questions.  Some contact centers simply provide a referring phone number, others actually create a knowledge item if the question comes in frequently enough.  But it's your decision.
311 is a simple, easy-to-remember number for constituents, which is probably the most compelling argument for using 311 directly.  That said, there are many jurisdictions that have established a contact center (it's more than phone calls...) using a dedicated 7-digit number.

author: Toni Messina
text:
You know, I have not found an explicit answer to this in the literature I've read so far.  If you have a 311 system, are you responsible for providing information outside your corporate jurisdiction?  I have been told that we would have LATA-wide responsibilities, which go beyond our experitise, but I have not been able to confirm.
On a related note, are there distinct, compelling advantages for establishing "311" over a seven-digit number?  Thanks for any information.
